title: 109_hr450
content: The Act may be cited as the "National Science Education Incentive Act of 2005". The Congress emphasizes the importance of maintaining the US's position in science and technology to advance human understanding and improve lives. Over half of the country's economic growth is attributed to these fields. The importance of research and development in science and technology is highlighted to advance human understanding and improve lives. Over half of the US's economic growth is directly linked to these fields, with fundamental research exploring the universe and seeking answers to new questions. Applied research then applies these findings to further progress. The United States' economic growth depends on its intellectual capital and innovativeness, with education playing a critical role in developing this resource. Applied research applies answers from basic science to everyday problems, making lives more meaningful and livable. The United States' economic growth relies on intellectual capital and innovativeness, with education being crucial for its development. Education programs should cater to scientists, engineers, and technologically proficient workers to support research and development for economic growth. The United States relies on research and development for economic growth, requiring technologically proficient workers and scientifically literate voters. Student performance in math and science shows shortcomings in K-12 education compared to other countries. The United States needs to improve K-12 science and mathematics education to compete globally. New teaching methods, better curricula, teacher training, and parental support are essential for success. Science goes beyond just facts and theories. Improving K-12 science and mathematics education in the United States requires new teaching methods, enhanced curricula, better teacher training, and strong parental involvement. Science is a process of inquiry based on observations and data, leading to a way of explaining the universe through concepts and theories. Students should learn science by actively engaging in experiments and focusing on concepts. Students should learn science primarily by doing science, reflecting the scientific process and being object-oriented, experiment-centered, and concept-based. Education in science should start at an early age and continue throughout the school experience, tapping into children's natural curiosity. Teachers play a crucial role in connecting students with the content they are learning, emphasizing the need for high-quality, well-trained prospective teachers. Teachers play a crucial role in connecting students with the content they are learning. High-quality, well-trained prospective teachers need to be recruited with incentives to remain in the classroom and improve their practice. Training of teachers is essential for superior results. Teachers must be knowledgeable in their content area and curriculum. Teachers must have incentives to remain in the classroom and improve their practice. Training is essential for superior results, with teachers needing knowledge of their content area, curriculum, up-to-date research, and effective teaching techniques. A new section is added to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, providing a refundable credit for undergraduate tuition paid by certain teachers. A new section in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 offers a refundable credit for eligible teachers based on 10% of qualified undergraduate tuition paid, with a maximum credit of $1,000 per year. Teachers in high-needs school districts may receive this credit for the first 5 taxable years. In high-needs school districts, eligible teachers teaching in elementary or secondary schools may receive a credit of $1,500 for the first 5 taxable years. No credit is allowed after the 10th year. In high-needs school districts, eligible teachers teaching in grades kindergarten through 12th grade may receive a $1,500 credit for the first 5 taxable years. No credit is allowed after the 10th year. Eligible teachers must be full-time teachers, including substitutes, for the academic year. Full-time teachers in grades K-12 for the academic year ending in a taxable year may qualify for a tax credit if they primarily teach math, science, engineering, or technology courses in grades 9-12 or K-8. Teachers in grades K-12 may qualify for a tax credit if they teach math, science, engineering, or technology courses in grades 9-12 or K-8, have a relevant degree, and are highly qualified. Teachers in grades K-12 may qualify for a tax credit if they teach math, science, engineering, or technology courses in grades 9-12 or K-8, have a relevant degree, and are highly qualified. School administrative functions can also be considered as teaching courses if they primarily relate to these subjects or are for a school focusing on them. Qualified undergraduate tuition is defined for this purpose. Qualified undergraduate tuition is defined as qualified higher education expenses for enrollment at an institution of higher education, as per section 529(e)(3) and section 25A(g)(2). An institution of higher education is defined in section 102 of the Higher Education Act of 1965. The text discusses the definition of an institution of higher education and the regulations that the Secretary shall prescribe to carry out the purposes of the section. Conforming amendments are also mentioned in relation to section 1324(b) of title 31, United States Code. Amendment made to section 1324(b) of title 31, United States Code by inserting "or 36" after "section 35". The table of sections for subpart C of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is also amended. Section 36 introduces tuition benefits for certain teachers, while section 37 addresses overpayments of tax. The effective date for these amendments is for taxable years starting after the enactment of the Act. Section 4 provides credits for contributions benefiting STEM education at the elementary and secondary school levels. Section 4 introduces credits for contributions benefiting STEM education at the elementary and secondary school levels under SEC. 45J of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The elementary and secondary STEM contributions credit under section 38 equals 100% of qualified STEM contributions, including STEM school contributions, teacher externship expenses, and teacher training expenses. The STEM school contributions include STEM property contributions and STEM service contributions. The STEM property contributions refer to the deductible amount for charitable contributions of STEM inventory property to elementary or secondary schools. The term "contributions" refers to the deductible amount for charitable contributions of STEM inventory property to elementary or secondary schools in the United States or defense dependents' education system for educational purposes in grades K-12. The deductible amount for charitable contributions of STEM inventory property to elementary or secondary schools in the United States or defense dependents' education system for educational purposes in grades K-12 includes criteria such as the property fitting into the donee's education plan and not being exchanged for money or other property. The deductible amount for charitable contributions of STEM inventory property to elementary or secondary schools in the United States or defense dependents' education system for educational purposes in grades K-12 includes criteria such as the property fitting into the donee's education plan and not being exchanged for money, other property, or services except for shipping, installation, and transfer costs. The donee's use and disposition of the property must comply with specific provisions. The term 'STEM service contributions' refers to payments made for STEM services provided in the US or defense dependents' education system for the benefit of students at specific schools, under certain conditions. The term 'STEM inventory property' refers to property donated to schools for STEM education, meeting specific criteria and conditions. The term 'STEM inventory property' refers to property donated to schools for STEM education, meeting specific criteria and conditions. It includes property described in section 1221(a) needed by schools for education in grades K-12 in STEM areas. STEM services are also defined as services needed by schools for providing education. The term 'STEM services' refers to services needed by schools for education in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics in grades K-12. The term 'defense dependents' education system' refers to the program established under the Defense Dependents' Education Act of 1978. The term 'STEM teacher externship expenses' refers to amounts paid for a STEM externship program involving eligible STEM teachers. The term 'STEM teacher externship expenses' refers to amounts paid for a STEM externship program where eligible STEM teachers participate. The program must be established by a taxpayer in the fields of science, technology, engineering, or mathematics. Eligible teachers may also receive stipends while participating in the program. The term 'STEM teacher externship expenses' refers to amounts paid for a program established by a taxpayer in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics. Eligible STEM teachers receive training to enhance their teaching skills in these areas. Eligible STEM teacher is defined as any individual who teaches in grades K-12 at an educational organization. An eligible STEM teacher is defined as an individual teaching in grades K-12 at an educational organization in the US or on a US military base, with teaching responsibilities in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics. The term 'STEM teacher training expenses' refers to amounts paid by a taxpayer in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics for eligible STEM teachers participating in a training program provided by the taxpayer's school. The text discusses the eligibility for a tax credit related to STEM teacher training expenses in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics. It mentions that no deduction is allowed if a credit is claimed. Additionally, there are conforming amendments to the tax code. The text introduces a new STEM contributions credit under section 45J of the tax code, specifically for elementary and secondary education. Conforming amendments are made to section 38(b) and the table of sections for subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1. The text introduces a new STEM contributions credit for elementary and secondary education. It also ensures that the Act does not allow federal control over educational institutions.
